name: Dharma Wheel
meaning: The Wheel of Dharma (Dharmachakra) represents the Buddha's teachings and the path to enlightenment. Its eight spokes symbolize the Noble Eightfold Path, the core ethical and mental guidelines for ending suffering.
description:
The Wheel of the Law, Symbol of Buddha's Teaching

The Dharmachakra (Sanskrit: dharma-cakra, 'Wheel of Dharma') is one of the oldest and most important symbols in Buddhism. It represents the Buddha's first teaching at Deer Park in Sarnath, when he 'set the wheel of Dharma in motion' (Dharmacakrapravartana). The wheel symbolizes the cyclical nature of existence, the path to liberation, and the eternal truth of the Buddha's teachings that continue to turn through all ages.

The Dharma Wheel is one of the Ashtamangala (Eight Auspicious Symbols) of Buddhism and appears throughout Buddhist art, architecture, and iconography across all traditions.
visualDescription:
The Dharmachakra is depicted as a wheel with eight spokes radiating from a central hub to an outer rim. Traditional representations feature:

**The Hub (Center):** Represents moral discipline (shila), the foundation of practice. In some interpretations, it contains three swirling shapes representing the Three Jewels (Buddha, Dharma, Sangha) or the overcoming of the Three Poisons (ignorance, attachment, aversion).

**The Eight Spokes:** Straight lines radiating outward, each representing one aspect of the Noble Eightfold Path: Right View, Right Intention, Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood, Right Effort, Right Mindfulness, and Right Concentration.

**The Rim:** The outer circle represents meditative concentration (samadhi) that holds the practice together. It also symbolizes the perfection and completeness of the teachings.

**Color Symbolism:** Often depicted in gold or saffron, representing the precious nature of the Dharma. In Tibetan Buddhism, the wheel may be ornamented with silk ribbons and jewels.

**Supporting Elements:** The wheel is frequently shown flanked by two deer, commemorating the Buddha's first sermon at Deer Park (Mrigadava) in Sarnath. This image adorns the rooftops of Tibetan monasteries.

hub.name: Hub (Nave)
hub.meaning: Moral discipline (Shila) - the center of ethical training
alternativeMeanings: The Three Jewels: Buddha, Dharma, Sangha
Overcoming the Three Poisons: Ignorance (Moha), Attachment (Raga), Aversion (Dvesha)
The mind or consciousness from which all practice radiates

spokes.name: Eight Spokes
spokes.meaning: The Noble Eightfold Path (Arya Ashtangika Marga)

components.description: Understanding the Four Noble Truths and the nature of reality
Commitment to ethical and mental self-improvement
Speaking truthfully, avoiding slander, gossip, and harsh words
Acting ethically, avoiding killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct
Earning a living without causing harm to others
Cultivating positive states and abandoning negative ones
Developing awareness of body, feelings, mind, and phenomena
Developing deep states of meditative absorption (jhana/dhyana)

rim.name: Rim (Felloe)
rim.meaning: Meditative concentration (Samadhi) that encompasses and unifies the practice
alternativeMeanings: The completeness and perfection of the Buddha's teachings
The unity of wisdom and method

threeTurnings.description: The Three Turnings of the Wheel of Dharma (Dharmachakra-pravartana) represent three major phases or levels of Buddhist teaching, recognized especially in Mahayana and Vajrayana Buddhism.

turnings.name: First Turning
turnings.teaching: The Four Noble Truths and Noble Eightfold Path
turnings.sutras: Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta (Setting the Wheel of Dharma in Motion)
turnings.focus: Individual liberation from suffering through understanding the nature of dukkha and following the path to nirvana

turnings.name: Second Turning
turnings.teaching: Emptiness (Shunyata) and the Perfection of Wisdom (Prajnaparamita)
turnings.sutras: Heart Sutra, Diamond Sutra, Prajnaparamita Sutras
turnings.focus: All phenomena are empty of inherent existence; emphasis on compassion and the Bodhisattva path

turnings.name: Third Turning
turnings.sutras: Lankavatara Sutra, Samdhinirmochana Sutra, Tathagatagarbha Sutra
turnings.focus: All beings possess Buddha-nature; clarification of emptiness teachings; foundation for Vajrayana

preBuddhist.description: The wheel symbol predates Buddhism and was an important royal emblem in ancient India
aspects: Symbol of the Chakravartin (wheel-turning universal monarch)
Associated with Surya, the Vedic sun god, whose chariot wheel traversed the sky
Ancient Indus Valley Civilization may have used wheel symbols
Connected to the concept of Rita (cosmic order) in Vedic tradition

chakravartin.description: The Chakravartin ideal deeply influenced the Dharma Wheel symbolism
chakravartin.meaning: Just as a Chakravartin's wheel rolls across the land bringing all under righteous rule, the Buddha's Dharma Wheel rolls across minds, bringing beings under the sovereignty of truth
chakravartin.connection: The Buddha is sometimes called the 'Dharma Chakravartin' - the wheel-turning emperor of spiritual truth

firstSermon.event: Dhammacakkappavattana - Setting the Wheel of Dharma in Motion
firstSermon.date: Full moon of Asadha (July), c. 528 BCE
firstSermon.location: Isipatana (Deer Park), Sarnath, near Varanasi, India
firstSermon.audience: The Five Ascetics (Kondanna, Vappa, Bhaddiya, Mahanama, Assaji)
firstSermon.significance: The Buddha's first teaching after his enlightenment, marking the beginning of the Buddhist Sangha and the Dharma as a living tradition

ashokaChakra.description: The Ashoka Chakra, derived from the Buddhist Dharma Wheel, appears on the flag of India
ashokaChakra.history: Emperor Ashoka (c. 268-232 BCE) erected pillars throughout his empire featuring the Dharma Wheel, most famously the Lion Capital at Sarnath

indianFlag.placement: Center of the flag, on the white stripe
indianFlag.meaning: The 24 spokes represent the 24 hours of the day, symbolizing that India should work for progress every hour. Also represents the 24 qualities of a righteous king (Dharmaraja) and continuous movement toward progress

lionCapital.description: Four Asiatic lions standing back to back, mounted on an abacus featuring a Dharma Wheel with a galloping horse, bull, elephant, and lion
lionCapital.currentStatus: National emblem of India; the original is housed in the Sarnath Museum

tibetanBuddhism.interpretation: In Vajrayana Buddhism, the Dharmachakra holds additional esoteric meanings
aspects: The wheel represents the union of wisdom (prajna) and skillful means (upaya)
Associated with the mandala principle - the center emanating enlightened activity
Connected to the chakra system in tantric practice
Represents the 'turning' of ordinary experience into enlightened awareness
ritualUse: Prayer wheels (mani wheels) containing mantras - spinning them 'turns' the Dharma
Placed atop temple rooftops flanked by two golden deer
Central image in many mandalas and thangka paintings
Used as a hand gesture (mudra) - Dharmachakra Mudra represents teaching

mudra.name: Dharmachakra Mudra
mudra.description: The 'Wheel-Turning' gesture: both hands held at chest level, left palm facing inward, right palm outward, with thumb and index fingers of each hand touching to form circles (representing the wheel), and the other fingers extended
mudra.meaning: The Buddha's teaching - the turning of the wheel of Dharma
mudra.usage: Depicted in images of Buddha Vairocana and representations of the Buddha's first sermon

artAndArchitecture.overview: The Dharma Wheel is one of the most widespread motifs in Buddhist art across all cultures and periods

examples.description: Large stone Dharma Wheels carved on the toranas (gateways)
Painted and carved Dharma Wheels in cave murals and sculptures
Multiple Dharma Wheel reliefs throughout the temple complex
Golden Dharma Wheels with flanking deer on monastery rooftops
Dharma Wheels in temple architecture, often with Naga (serpent) imagery

artAndArchitecture.aniconic: In early Buddhist art, before Buddha images were created, the Dharma Wheel was used to represent the Buddha himself, particularly when depicting the first sermon

relatedSymbols.name: Ashtamangala
relatedSymbols.description: The Eight Auspicious Symbols of Buddhism, of which the Dharma Wheel is one

relatedSymbols.name: Wheel of Becoming (Bhavachakra)
relatedSymbols.description: The Wheel of Life depicting the six realms of existence and the twelve links of dependent origination
relatedSymbols.difference: While the Dharmachakra represents liberation, the Bhavachakra represents cyclic existence (samsara)

relatedSymbols.name: Sudarshana Chakra
relatedSymbols.description: The discus weapon of Lord Vishnu in Hindu tradition
relatedSymbols.connection: Shares the wheel symbolism of divine power and cosmic order

primarySources.title: Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta
primarySources.description: The Buddha's first discourse, setting forth the Four Noble Truths and the Middle Way

primarySources.title: Lalitavistara Sutra
primarySources.description: Detailed account of the Buddha's life including the first turning of the wheel

primarySources.title: Samdhinirmochana Sutra
primarySources.description: Describes the Three Turnings of the Wheel of Dharma

ritualUsage:
The Dharma Wheel is used extensively in Buddhist practice and ceremony:

- **Temple Architecture**: Placed prominently on monastery rooftops, often with flanking deer representing the Deer Park sermon
- **Prayer Wheels (Mani Wheels)**: Cylinders containing mantras that practitioners spin to 'turn' the Dharma and accumulate merit
- **Meditation Focus**: Used as a visualization object representing the Buddha's teachings
- **Ordination Ceremonies**: Symbolizing the candidate's entry into the wheel of Dharma
- **Festival Celebrations**: Especially Dharma Day (Asalha Puja), celebrating the first sermon
- **Merit-Making**: Creating or sponsoring Dharma Wheel images is considered highly meritorious
meanings: The Buddha's first teaching at Sarnath - 'Setting the Wheel of Dharma in Motion'
The Noble Eightfold Path to liberation from suffering
The continuous teaching of Dharma across all times and places
The cyclical nature of existence and the path to transcend it
The union of wisdom and compassion in Buddhist practice
The Three Turnings representing progressive revelation of Buddhist truth
Universal sovereignty of truth over all beings
The perfect completeness of the Buddha's teaching
attributes: One of the Eight Auspicious Symbols

variations.name: Standard Eight-Spoked Wheel
variations.description: The most common form, representing the Noble Eightfold Path

variations.name: Thousand-Spoked Wheel
variations.description: Found on Buddha's footprints, representing countless aspects of the teaching

variations.name: Ashoka Chakra (24 spokes)
variations.description: The wheel on India's national flag, derived from Ashokan pillars

variations.name: Wheel with Deer
variations.description: The wheel flanked by two kneeling deer, commemorating the Deer Park sermon

variations.name: Prayer Wheel Form
variations.description: Cylindrical form containing mantras, designed to be spun

variations.name: Tibetan Ornate Style
variations.description: Elaborately decorated with jewels, silk ribbons, and flame aureole

origins: Ancient Buddhist tradition; the wheel predates Buddhism in Indian culture (associated with Chakravartin kings)
usage: Central symbol in Buddhist temples, prayer wheels, meditation, ordination ceremonies; represents the first sermon at Sarnath
prohibitions: Not to be used as mere decoration without understanding its spiritual significance
Should not be turned clockwise (counterclockwise is traditional)
Respect required when depicted in prayer wheels or temple settings
Avoid depiction on disrespectful or trivial items
